answers.author: Adam Szumski
answers.text:
Charlotte,
The ICMA Center for Performance Measurement collects comparative code enforcement and permitting data annually from our 200-plus participants. The measures we track include service descriptions (how a department is set up), staffing, inputs, workload (e.g. inspections per year per inspection employee), and performance (e.g. the percent of inspections completed on time, same day, and within 4 calendar days).
Last year, CPM participants averaged nearly 2,000 inspections per year per full-time equivalent (FTE), and there was considerable variability by jurisdiction size. However, that number is not a “standard” in anyway, and there are many factors that may suggest to a jurisdiction what staffing they need to provide effective inspection services to their city.
For more information about the Center and the types of measures we collect, please contact Rebecca VanRegenmorter at (rvanregenmorter@icma.org; 202-962-3585).

answers.author: Eric Johnson
answers.text:
There are a variety of factors to consider: Travel time between inspections, complexity of construction being inspected (e.g., cookie-cutter residential versus unique non-residential), whether inspectors are cross-trained (so that the same inspector can perform inspections of different types while in the same subdivision), whether they get their assignments electronically without first reporting in each day to a central location, etc. 
When we compared notes with a neighboring county, we were advised that they faced penalty in their ISO rating for having too many inspections per day per inspector. (We have not confirmed that is an ISO criterion.) 
We recently initiated a contract so that we can supplement in-house inspections with contract inspections to avoid some of the hire/layoff pattern of the past and to more easily flex our inspections capacity on short notice. While we are new to that approach, I imagine there are others with enough experience to share how well that has worked for them.

answers.author: Michael Robertson
answers.text:
When we reached that point in a previous community, we hired a contract building inspections firm.  They were willing to flex their hours to meet our needs.  We would use them anywhere from ten hour per week to fifty.  When we were consistently exceeding forty hours a week we knew it was then justifiable to hire a full time employee.  However, the City Council enjoyed the flexibility of a contractor and decided to stay with them.

answers.text:
In Atlanta, we are finding that because of the traffic and the required travel time from one end of the City to the other, that we need to assign each Inspector an "area" to eliminate as much as  possible to need to criss cross the city during the inspection process.

author: Charlotte Presensky
text: What standards are utilized to determine the number of inspections a building inspector can conduct effectively in one day?  We are looking to determine at what point we will need to consider hiring.
title: Building Inspector - number of inspections per day?
